item.title: Useful Git Commands
item.description: Stash Commands Stash tracked files 1 git stash save "stash message" Stash tracked and untracked files 1 git stash save -u "stash message" View stashes 1 git stash list Apply stash by id (Doesn’t delete from stash) 1 git stash apply stash@{0} Unstash a single, specific file from a stash 1 git diff stash@{0}^1 stash@{0} -- <filename> Cleaning / Deletion In case you have not pushed the commit publicly yet, and want to undo it, keeping the changes in your working directory: 1 git reset HEAD~1 --soft Dry (-n) run for git clean for recursive directory (-d) deletion of untracked files: 1 git clean -n -d Delete all untracked files from the repository (ignores files in .

item.title: Vim
item.description: Why Vim? Learning to use Vim is worth it for several reasons. First, Vim (or vi) is almost guaranteed to be installed on any remote server you may need to ssh into.
